what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: package implements multi-scale Truchet tiles Christopher Carlson explained blog post. implementation uses package {sf} create manipulate spatial objects. Two functions used create tiles arrange tiles mosaic. Since tiles mosaics simple features, can plotted using {ggplot2} geom_sf(). addition, manipulations tiles (buffering) can done using functionality {sf}.

what: Tile of type “d” or “\” and “/” in Carlson’s notation.
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Using function st_truchet_p() type “d” produces data frame elements two tiles, diagonal left (“\”) diagonal right (“/”). addition geometry spatial elements tiles, data frame includes identifiers tiles (.e., tile 1 “\” tile 2 “/”) well colors.

what: Tile of type “-” or “-” and “|” in Carlson’s notation.
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Using function st_truchet_p() type “-” produces data frame elements two tiles, horizontal (“-”) vertical (“|”). addition geometry spatial elements tiles, data frame includes identifiers tiles (.e., tile 1 “|” tile 2 “-”) well colors.

what: Tile of type “f” in Carlson’s notation.
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Using function st_truchet_p() type “f” produces data frame elements four tiles, corresponding “fne” (tile 1), “fsw” (tile 2), “fse” (tile 3) “fnw” (tile 4) Carlson’s notation. addition geometry spatial elements tiles, data frame includes identifiers tiles colors.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Carlson’s tiles designed work multiple scales. moment, function create tiles supports scale 1 (tiles squares sides length 1) scale 1/2 (sides tile length 1/2). Argument scale_p can used select scale tiles (default 1). Notice colors alternate scale.
code: st_truchet_p(type = "d", scale_p = 1/2) %>%   ggplot() +   geom_sf(aes(fill = factor(color))) +   facet_wrap(~tile)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: tiles can used inputs create mosaics using function st_truchet_ms() example shows single tile: type tile produces two distinct tiles. Use 1 type create mosaic: Retrieve “container” mosaic mosaic: Plot:  Use two tiles type
code: tiles_1 <- st_truchet_p(type = "d") summary(tiles_1) #>      color            tile             geometry #>  Min.   :1.000   Min.   :1.0   MULTIPOLYGON:2   #>  1st Qu.:1.250   1st Qu.:1.0   POLYGON     :4   #>  Median :2.000   Median :1.5   epsg:NA     :0   #>  Mean   :1.667   Mean   :1.5                    #>  3rd Qu.:2.000   3rd Qu.:2.0                    #>  Max.   :2.000   Max.   :2.0 mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1 %>%                            filter(tile == 1)) container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]] ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA) mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1)  container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]]  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Various tile types can combined: Note identifier tile needs updated second set tiles, mosaic assembler knows different types tiles provided. Create mosaic plot:
code: tiles_1 <- rbind(st_truchet_p(type = "d"),                  st_truchet_p(type = "-") %>%                    mutate(tile = tile + 2)) mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1)  container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]]  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Tiles different scales can combined single mosaic: tiles placed regular grid spacing 1--1. tiles scale 1/2 used instead 1 tile four used cover unit square. parameter prop controls proportion spots grid used tiles scale 1 (default 0.5):  next plot proportion tiles scale 1 increased:  decreased:
code: tiles_1 <- st_truchet_p(type = "f") tiles_2 <- st_truchet_p(type = "f", scale_p = 1/2) mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1, tiles_2)  container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]]  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA) mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1, tiles_2, prop = 0.85)  container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]]  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA) mosaic <- st_truchet_ms(tiles_1, tiles_2, prop = 0.25)  container <- mosaic[["container"]] mosaic <- mosaic[["mosaic"]]  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mosaic,           aes(fill = factor(color)),           color = NA)
